title: A clear Johnson win can tame the Brexit demons
text:
It’s been his party’s tragedy that a foolish choice of leader has made them impotent in a prolonged national crisis. Labour has finally managed to agree to offer another referendum if it wins, which will mortify some voters, though attract others.

Second thoughts on Brexit might see traditional concerns like health and public services resurface as voter priorities, as they did in the 2017 election. There are some extreme characters campaigning too, with much potential for fatal gaffes. And Parliament itself is on trial. Mr Johnson says that Parliament has held the country hostage. Others say Parliament has just done its job in questioning the result of an ill-conceived plebiscite that clashes for legitimacy with Britain’s sovereign parliamentary system.

British Prime Minister Boris Johnson and Opposition Leader Jeremy Corbyn. Getty

The jury is still out on the economic stakes, and the real worth of the Brexit exercise. Many of the promises of the Brexiteers have been a mirage. But former Bank of England governor Mervyn King has said it will be neither the end of the world, nor the promised land. His successor Mark Carney says the British economy is flexible enough to adapt to being outside the EU.

This isn’t just economics, however. The British launched the first Industrial Revolution, and they were Karl Marx’s classic proletariat and bourgeoisie. But as Australian Labor MP Clare O’Neil says today in The Australian Financial Review, the Venn diagram of politics is shifting far beyond the old economic left and right. There are now many political identities.

Even while the Conservatives have self-destructed in full view of the world for three years, Jeremy Corbyn has looked worse.

In the age of globalisation, it is the revolt of the localised, cultural “somewheres” that has such force. That is what has made Brexit cut across normal economic self-interest to more visceral belief in taking back national control. It’s echoed by Donald Trump, or even Prime Minister Scott Morrison’s pushback at the “unaccountable internationalist bureaucracy” of the United Nations.

By contrast Mr Corbyn’s promises of worker control at companies, or squeezing the rich, could be obscured by the culture war that middle-class “anywhere” lefties have waged on the working class and poor white sensibilities for decades. Centre-left parties from western Sydney to West Virginia are struggling to understand this rift.

The bookies give equal odds to Conservative or Labour minority government in December. Thankfully they judge a Conservative majority vastly more likely than a Labour one - and a solid win for Mr Johnson is the only resolution.

Another referendum, after the 52-48 result delivered by the half-baked plebiscite of 2016, would only ensure that another contested result raged on. That would weaken the UK and the European Union too, neither of which is in the interest of Australia and the wider West.
description: Brexit revealed a culture war in British politics. Only a definitive Tory win that sees the referendum acted upon can start to ease it.
